intro: Haplopappus pallidus, commonly known as the pale pappus, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and distinctive inflorescence structure. The plant typically grows in arid or semi-arid environments, showcasing its adaptability to harsh conditions. Its foliage is usually gray-green, with narrow, linear leaves that reduce water loss. The flowers are small and yellow, arranged in clusters, contributing to its ecological role in supporting pollinators.
